name: AAAS1000
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Keywords, themes, and career paths in Asian American Studies; critical and historical perspective on Asian diasporic peoples in the United States within a global framework. Topics may include popular culture, history, social justice, and activism. CA 1. CA 4.

name: AAAS2030
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Asian art and propaganda in the Cold War era (1949-1991) and its relation to Europe, the Soviet Union, and the United States. May include analysis of visual arts, film, photography, and multimedia.

name: AAAS2201
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary introduction to major themes in Asian American Studies. Concepts of identity and community, migration and labor histories, Asians and the law, representations of Asians in visual and popular culture, gender issues, interracial and interethnic relations, and human rights. CA 1. CA 4.

name: AAAS2530
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of Asian American experiences in the United States since 1850.  Responses by Asian Americans to both opportunities and discrimination.

name: AAAS3212
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Literature, theatre, film about Asian American communities and culture in the United States from the mid-nineteenth century to the present. CA 4.

name: AAAS3221
catalogName: Sociological Perspectives on Asian American Women
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: An overview of social structures, inter-group relations, and women' s rights, focusing on the experience of Asian American women. CA 4.

name: AAAS3222
catalogName: Asian Indian Women: Activism and Social Change in India and the United States
prerequisites: SOCI 1001, 1251 or 1501; open to juniors or higher.
description: How gender, class, and ethnicity/race structure everyday lives of Asian Indian women in both India and the United States.

name: AAAS3531
catalogName: Japanese Americans and World War II
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The events leading to martial law and executive order 9066, the wartime experience of Japanese Americans, and national consequences. Formerly offered as AASI 3531. CA 1. CA 4.

name: AAAS3808
catalogName: East Asia to the Mid-Nineteenth Century
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The major problems and issues of traditional Chinese and Japanese history and historiography. Special emphasis on the "Great Tradition" in ideas of both civilizations.

name: AAAS3809
catalogName: East Asia Since the Mid-Nineteenth Century
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The reactions of East Asia to the Western threat, and the rise of Asian nationalism, communism, and fascism. Special attention to the tensions caused by the conflict of ideas.

name: AAAS3822
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of patterns of modern China since 1800. Topics will include reforms and revolutions, industrialization and urbanization, and family and population growth. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: AAAS3842
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Introduction to the history of the Vietnamese from the late Bronze Age to the present: the ancient culture of the Red River delta, the millennium of Chinese rule, the independent kingdom of Dai Viet and its successors, French colonialism, the Vietnam War, and postwar Vietnam.

name: AAAS3998
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in topic, may be repeated once for credit. Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: AAAS4100
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary examination of the history of social justice organizing in the U.S.; theories, strategies, and practice of community organizing movements such as those for immigration, environmental, reproductive, and racial justice. Includes practice in community organizing and political advocacy.

name: AAAS4999
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Credits, not to exceed three per semester, and hours by arrangement. With a change of subject, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: ACCT2001
prerequisites: Not recommended for first year students. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ACCT  2101, 3005, or 3260.
description: The study of the generation and interpretation of accounting information as a basis for financial statement analysis and management decision-making.

name: ACCT2101
prerequisites: ACCT 2001; open only to Business majors of sophomore or higher status. Not open to students who have passed or are taking BADM 2710 or 3710. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ACCT 3201, 3221, or 4881.
description: Internal reporting to managers for use in planning and controlling operating systems, for use in decision making, formulating major plans and policies, and for costing products for inventory valuation and income determination.

name: ACCT3005
prerequisites: ACCT 2001 which may be taken concurrently; open only to Business majors of sophomore or higher status. Required for Accounting majors.
description: Designed to help students (1) understand the professional responsibilities of accountants, (2) enhance one's knowledge of the structure of the accounting profession and the reporting process, (3) evaluate alternative accounting careers, and (4) prepare for accounting internship and career opportunities. Consists of a series of evening seminars. Topics include (among others): alternative accounting careers, accounting standard setting, professional certification for accountants, and analysis and interpretation of accounting information. The course will also introduce and allow students to interact with UConn accounting alumni in a variety of accounting careers.

name: ACCT3201
prerequisites: ACCT 2101 or BADM 2710; ECON 1200 or both ECON 1201 and 1202; open only to business majors of junior or higher status. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ACCT 3202 or 4881. Not open for credit to students who have passed BADM 3201.
description: An in-depth study of financial accounting, giving particular emphasis to balance sheet valuations and their relationship to income determination.

name: ACCT3202
prerequisites: ACCT 3201 or BADM 3201; open only to business majors of junior or higher status. Not open for credit to students who have passed or are taking BADM 3202. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ACCT 4203 or 4243.
description: A continuation of ACCT 3201/BADM 3201.

name: ACCT3221
prerequisites: ACCT 2101 or BADM 2710; OPIM 3103, which may be taken concurrently; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.
description: The study of (1) product costing as a basis for income determination and inventory valuation and (2) accounting concepts for planning and controlling organizational operations.

name: ACCT3260
prerequisites: ACCT 2001; open only to business majors of junior or higher status. Not open for credit to students who have passed BADM 3260. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ACCT 4261.
description: A study of the underlying concepts of federal income taxation. Emphasis to be placed upon the impact of taxes on business decisions.

name: ACCT3265
catalogName: Volunteer Income Tax Assistance for Preparers
prerequisites: ACCT 2001; open only to business majors of sophomore or higher status. Not open for credit for students in or who have passed BADM 3265. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ACCT 4265.
description: IRS Certification in Basic Domestic and International Student and Scholar tax returns. Research and analyze current tax issues, interview a diverse group of real taxpayers, prepare real returns and respond to immediate feedback while working in a controlled setting under the supervision of a CPA. Students learn practical accounting and tax skills and procedures, while providing a valuable service to our community.  Gives students the rare opportunity to gain technical industry experience in an academic environment. ACCT/BADM 4265 can be taken for one credit subsequent to ACCT/BADM 3265. Students in ACCT/BADM 4265 serve as qualified reviewers.

name: ACCT4203
prerequisites: ACCT 3202 or BADM 3202; open only to Business majors of junior or higher status. Not open for credit to students who have passed or are taking ACCT 5603.
description: An in-depth study of accounting for business combinations. Coverage will also be given to accounting for nonprofit entities and contemporary issues in financial accounting.

name: ACCT4204
catalogName: Financial Statement Analysis and Business Valuation
prerequisites: Open only to business majors of junior or higher status. Recommended for Honors students. Recommended preparation: ACCT 3202 or BADM 3202.
description: Advances the understanding of financial information to analyze and value firms. Involves the application of accounting, economics, finance and other skills to better understand information contained in financial reports.

name: ACCT4243
prerequisites: ACCT 3202 or BADM 3202; open only to business majors of junior or higher status. Not open for credit to students who have passed or are taking BADM 4243.
description: Focuses on issues relevant to the public accounting profession, such as legal liability and ethics, audit risk analysis, planning of audit engagements, audit reports, and other assurance services and reports. Students will learn to think critically about issues facing the accounting profession, primarily by analyzing cases and completing a number of individual and group research projects.

name: ACCT4261
prerequisites: ACCT 3260 or BADM 3260; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.
description: Application of basic tax concepts to business entities, with particular emphasis on C corporations and partnerships. At the end of the course, students should be able to identify and address the tax issues faced when forming, operating, and liquidating a business entity.

name: ACCT4265
catalogName: Advanced Volunteer Income Tax Assistance for Reviewers
prerequisites: ACCT 3265 or BADM 3265; open only to Business majors of sophomore or higher status. Not open for credit for students in or who have completed BADM 4265.
description: Advanced IRS Certification in Domestic and International Student and Scholar tax returns. Research and analyze current tax issues on an advanced level, with supervisory responsibility, while working in a controlled setting under the supervision of a CPA. Students develop mentoring skills as well as supplement practical accounting and tax skills, while providing a valuable service to our community. Gives students the rare opportunity to gain technical industry experience in an academic environment.

name: ACCT4997W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to Accounting Department honors students; open to juniors or higher.
description: Open only to  Accounting Department Honors Students with consent of instructor and department head.

name: AFRA2211
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing AFRA 4994.
description: Interdisciplinary overview of Africana studies, giving consideration to the artistic, intellectual, political and cultural experiences of black people in the United States, Caribbean, Europe, and Africa. Significant movements, ideas, people and events that have shaped and continue to shape Africa and the Diaspora.

name: AFRA2214W
description: Critical and historical examination of the literature of African American writers from Phyllis Wheatley to the present. CA 4.

name: AFRA3033
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Examination of contemporary public policy through the lens of race.

name: AFRA3106
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Empirical and theoretical literature on psychological experiences of African Americans. Impact of race, culture, and ethnicity on psychological development. CA 4.

name: AFRA3131
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The significant developments in African American theatre and its antecedents and an examination of selected play scripts that exemplify those developments. CA 4.

name: AFRA3132
catalogName: African-American Women Playwrights, 1900 to the present
prerequisites: Rec Prep: AFRA/DRAM 3131
description: African American women's playwriting in relationship to social, historical, and political contexts. CA 1. CA 4.

name: AFRA3152
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Popular and scholarly theories of human group identity and diversity, in cross-cultural and historical perspective. Topics include: an overview of 'race' and 'ethnicity' in Western thought, ethnic group formation and transformation, political mobilizations of group identity, and systems of inequality. CA 2. CA 4.

name: AFRA3206
description: Major themes in recent scholarship of African-descended communities in the Americas and their interconnection beyond geopolitical boundaries; race, gender, sexuality, class, religion, cultural movements and practices, slavery, political economy, political movements, and African consciousness, from historical perspective. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: AFRA3213
catalogName: Eighteenth- and Nineteenth-Century African American Literature
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Broad historical survey of African American literature from its origins through the turn of the twentieth century. CA 4.

name: AFRA3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Supervised reading and writing on a subject of special interest to the student.

name: AFRA3501
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Ethnic groups, their interrelations, assimilation, and pluralism. Culture, and identity that arise from differences in race, religion, nationality, region, and language.

name: AFRA3505
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The origin, nature, and consequences of white racism as a central and enduring social principle around which the United States and other modern societies are structured and evolve. CA 4.

name: AFRA3563
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of African-American people to 1865, from their West African roots, to their presence in colonial America, through enslavement and emancipation. Adaptation and resistance to their conditions in North America. Contributions by black people to the development of the United States.

name: AFRA3564
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of African-American people since the Civil war. Contributions by black people to American development. African-American activity in international arenas.

name: AFRA3568
catalogName: Hip Hop, Politics and Youth Culture in America
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of hip-hop, its musical antecedents and its role in popular culture. Race, class, and gender are examined as well as hip-hop's role in popular political discourse.

name: AFRA3618
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The rise and fall of trans-Atlantic slavery. Topics include resistance, migration, antislavery mobilization, abolitionism, empire, revolution, cultural production, political economy, labor, gender, race and identity formation.

name: AFRA3622
catalogName: History of Gender and Sexuality in Latin America and the Caribbean
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Topics may include: empire and colonialism/anti-colonialism; slavery, science, and the state; cultural practices and institutions; feminisms and masculinities; law and public policies; immigration; forms of labor and political mobilization; sex and reproduction; and human rights from historical perspective.

name: AFRA3642
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Political behavior, theory, and ideology of African-Americans, with emphasis on contemporary U.S. politics. CA 4.

name: AFRA3647
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Black leadership, emphasizing the principles, goals, and strategies used by African-American men and women to secure basic citizenship rights during the civil rights era.

name: AFRA3752
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of pre-colonial Africa with particular attention to the rise and fall of African Kingdoms, interaction between different ethnic groups, African trade with other continents, and the impact of foreigners on African societies.

name: AFRA3753
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of African perceptions of and responses to the abolition of the slave trade, Western imperialism and colonialism, and the development of nationalism and struggle for independence.

name: AFRA3898
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change of topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: AFRA4994W
prerequisites: AFRA 3211; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to AFRA majors in their senior year.
description: Critical training and comprehensive examination of African American studies, using primary and secondary sources. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: AGNR1089
catalogName: Introduction to Research in Agriculture and Natural Resources
prerequisites: Open to Freshman or Sophomore students only.
description: Supervised student involvement with faculty projects to introduce students to current areas of research in their field of interest. May be repeated with change of topic for a maximum of 6 credits. Credits and hours by arrangement. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) of U (unsatisfactory).

name: AGNR3091
prerequisites: Junior or senior in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.
description: Designed to provide students with a meaningful experience in a formalized agricultural or natural resources program under supervised conditions. Each student taking this course must submit a formal written report for evaluation and meet all other course requirements as specified by the instructor. May be repeated for credit with the total credits earned not to exceed six.

name: AGNR3093
prerequisites: Department consent required.
description: Courses taken in agriculture, natural resources, and related areas as part of approved Study Abroad programs. Credits and topics must be approved by department head or dean of the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources. May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: AGNR3095
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated with a change of topic.

name: AGNR3099
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A course designed for the student who wishes to pursue an investigation of specific problems related to domestic and foreign agriculture with particular emphasis on current problems in instruction, extension education, and research.  May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: AGNR3316
catalogName: Introduction to Agricultural Mechanics and Safety
prerequisites: Open only to students majoring in Agriculture and Natural Resources, Animal Science, Horticulture, Natural Resources, Turfgrass & Soil Science, and Sustainable Plant and Soil Systems.
description: Operation, safety, and applications of equipment and mechanical systems used in agricultural enterprises.  Field Trips may be required.

name: AGNR3350
catalogName: Hispanic Culture and Communication in Agriculture
prerequisites: Open only to students in the College of Agriculture, Health and Natural Resources.
description: Covers everyday conversations in Latin American Spanish needed at the workplace in agriculture and natural resources.  It aims at emphasizing dialogues, commands and directions to improve the relationship and understanding of workers and employers in several fields of agriculture.  Course prepares students in landscape, horticulture, animal science and agriculture economics with basic communication skills in Spanish and familiarizes students with Latin American cultural traditions. Taught with SAAG 350. Not intended for students with advanced Spanish language skill.  Does not fulfill the General Education foreign language requirement.

name: AGNR3610
catalogName: Leadership in Agriculture, Health and Natural Resources II
prerequisites: Open only to students in the College Ambassador Program; instructor consent required.
description: For students accepted into the College Ambassador Program. Introduces students to leadership theory and development, with a focus on group and citizenship values. A continuation of AGNR 3600. Taught with SAAG 361.

name: AGNR4100
prerequisites: Open only to seniors in the College of Agriculture, Health and Natural Resources
description: Enhances preparedness for post-college life in and outside of the office. Develops skills and strategies for creating personal growth and professional success. Topics include personal finances, emotional intelligence, professional development, community involvement, and lifestyle.

name: AGNR4500
prerequisites: Junior or senior standing or graduate student.  Open to students from the College of Agriculture, Health and Natural Resources. Others with instructor permission.
description: Introduces students to Extension, outreach education and other forms of public engagement (governmental and nongovernmental).  It is intended for students interested in a career in or knowing about outreach education and public engagement.  The Extension mission, history, organization, programming, program development, extension teaching and delivery methods, and the involvement and use of volunteers will be covered. Students will learn about and practice team-based collaborations, informal teaching/learning methods as well as social processes and influences, organizational behavior and relationships, program evaluation and assessment, communications, ethics, and decision-making.

name: AH1030
prerequisites: Open to freshmen and sophomores in the Honors Program.
description: Explores the biology of obesity including genetic predispositions and behaviors that increase obesity risk (dietary, physical activity, social, psychological), the obesigenic environment, including how communities are physically built, as well as the economic relationship to obesity risk, and policy and ethical implications for obesity prevention. Multi-level obesity prevention approaches that involve the individual, family, organization, community, and policy. CA 3.

name: AH1100
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Overview of health professions, team approach to health care delivery.

name: AH1200
prerequisites: Students may not exceed three credits toward graduation of combined AH 1200 and KINS 1160 credits.
description: Introduction to the techniques and philosophies of traditional Martial Arts disciplines. Development of practical martial arts skills (varies by discipline), and building of a state of mind which permits the successful application of self-defense. This course may be repeated with a change of activity and/or skill level.

name: AH2001
prerequisites: Open to CAHNR students and following majors: Biological Sciences; Health Care Management; HDFS; MCB; NURS; Pharmacy Studies; PNB; PSYC; SLHS; DGS; MLS and others by instructor consent.
description: Introduction and mastery of medical terminology through presentation of word roots, prefixes and suffixes. Disease processes, symptoms, diagnosis, and treatments that affect various body systems. Terminology associated with disease processes, symptoms, diagnosis, clinical procedures, laboratory tests, and treatments that affect various body systems.

name: AH3000
catalogName: U.S. Healthcare System and Professional Practice
prerequisites: Open only to Allied Health Sciences majors juniors and higher, others by consent. Not open to students who have passed NURS 1130 or AH 2000.
description: Essentials of the U.S. healthcare system, its history to present day structure including the role of the government and delivery systems; patient, ethical and legal responsibility; financing and reimbursement structures; and Allied Health professionals' practice within the system.

name: AH3005
prerequisites: A course in pre-calculus or higher; STAT 1000Q or 1100Q or higher. Open to CAHNR students and Statistics majors, juniors or higher; others with instructor consent.  Not open for credit to students who have passed STAT 4625.
description: Introduction to biostatistical techniques, concepts, and reasoning using in a broad range of biomedical and public health related scenarios. Specific topics include description of data, statistical hypothesis testing and its application to group comparisons, and tools for modeling different type of data, including categorical, and time-event, data. Emphasis on the distinction of these methods, their implementation using statistical software, and the interpretation of results applied to health sciences research questions and variables.

name: AH3021
prerequisites: BIOL 1107; CHEM 2241 or 2443; open to juniors or higher; open to ENVS and Allied Health Sciences majors, others with instructor consent. Concurrent enrollment in one of the following is strongly recommended: MCB 2000, 2410, 2413 or 2210, 3010.
description: Basic principles in tumor biology will be presented including the biochemical basis of cell transformation, proliferation, and metastasis. Molecular mechanisms by which environmental chemicals interact with DNA and other cellular components will be discussed. The role of proto-oncogenes, tumor suppressor genes, and their products will be covered. Biological markers of cancer risk and exposure will be included.

name: AH3025
catalogName: Human Physiology in Health and Disease
prerequisites: BIOL 1107; open to juniors or higher in the following majors: Allied Health Sciences, Diagnostic Genetic Sciences, Environmental Sciences (Human Health concentration only), Exercise Science, Medical Laboratory Sciences, and Nutritional Sciences; others with instructor consent. Students who have passed PNB 2264 or 2274 or equivalent, including transfer equivalents, will receive only two credits for AH 3025 but three credits will be used for calculating GPA.
description: An overview of the structure and function of the human body in health and common pathologic conditions associated with each organ system. Does not satisfy the anatomy and physiology admission requirements for undergraduate or post-baccalaureate health programs that require anatomy and physiology with lab.

name: AH3091
prerequisites: Open to Department of Allied Health Sciences students; open to juniors or higher.
description: Provides Allied Health students actual work experience in their area of concentration. Students work with professionals in their concentration to meet objectives consistent with their major. Students may only count a maximum combined credit total of six credits toward the Allied Health major of International Study, Independent Study and Internship credits.

name: AH3099
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Individualized study in a specialized area in the field of allied health.  May be repeated for credit. Students may only count a maximum combined credit total of 6 credits toward the Allied Health major of International Study, Independent Study and Internship credits.

name: AH3101
prerequisites: BIOL 1103 or 1107 or equivalent; open to juniors or higher; open to Allied Health Sciences majors, others with instructor consent.  Not open to students who have passed AH 1201.
description: Wellness, holistic health, mind-body connection, health and wellness models, mental wellness, positive self-concept, preventing heart disease and cancer, licit and illicit drugs, stress management, diet, nutrition, weight control, aerobic and anaerobic exercise, healthy lifestyle behaviors, application to life.  All students are required to participate in at least one Community Based Outreach Engagement Program.

name: AH3121
catalogName: Immunology for the Medical Laboratory Sciences
prerequisites: MLSC 3130 or MCB 2610 which may be taken concurrently; open to students in: Allied Health Sciences, Diagnostic Genetic Sciences, Medical Laboratory Sciences and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences certificate students; open to juniors or higher.
description: Mechanisms of innate and acquired immunity, antigen-antibody interactions, function of the human immune system in normal and diseased states.

name: AH3133
prerequisites: One course in Biology which may be taken concurrently; open to juniors or higher; open only to Allied Health Sciences majors, others by instructor consent.
description: Introduces cancer risk reduction education, causes, early detection methods, prevention, and public education.

name: AH3173
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher; BGS students or Allied Health Sciences OSH concentration majors, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: one 1000-level or above PSYC course.
description: Knowledge of the human factors and behaviors that have an impact upon the safety performance of employees in the workplace, and intervention strategies to improve individual and organizational safety performance.

name: AH3175E
prerequisites: BIOL 1102 or higher; CHEM 1122 or higher; open to Allied Health Sciences, Environmental Sciences, Environmental Studies and Engineering majors, others with instructor consent; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: a course in animal anatomy and physiology.
description: The environmental health consequences of exposure to toxic chemicals, food contaminants and radiation. Basic principles of toxicology and topics such as cancer, occupational hazards, radiation, genetic biomonitoring, risk assessment techniques, risk/benefit analysis, social/legal aspects of regulating toxic chemicals, and other related topics.

name: AH3203
prerequisites: Open to Allied Health Sciences majors, others with instructor consent; open to juniors or higher.
description: Age-related physiological changes and pathologies, health behaviors and care issues unique to older populations, interdisciplinary approaches to diagnosis, treatment, prevention and health promotion.

name: AH3231
prerequisites: Open to students pursuing a Health Promotion concentration, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.
description: Presents meaningful and constructive tools, methods and techniques for Health Care practitioners to plan, develop and deliver community based (outreach) Health Promotion programs which would provide opportunities to improve the quality of life as well as the quantity.

name: AH3234
prerequisites: Open only to Allied Health Sciences majors, others with instructor consent; open to juniors or higher.
description: Emphasizes preventative health practices, which promote healthful lifestyles and reduce risk factors associated with disease.  Designed to provide theory and concepts related to the development and maintenance of physical fitness, general health and performance.

name: AH3275
prerequisites: Open only to Allied Health Sciences majors, Environmental Science majors, Environmental Engineering majors, and students in the Occupational Safety &Health program, other with instructor consent; open to juniors or higher.
description: Provides individuals the necessary knowledge and training to meet the criteria for certification recognized by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) in work activities related to hazardous waste sites and clean up operations involving hazardous substances. Mandatory off-site field exercise required.

name: AH3278
catalogName: Workers' Compensation Law and Related Issues
prerequisites: Open only to BGS students and Allied Health Sciences OEHS and Healthcare Administration concentration majors juniors or higher, and OSH Certificate students; others with consent.
description: Review of the application of worker's compensation laws to workplace injuries and illnesses inclusive of the handling of filed claims, available benefits, medical management, return-to-work programs, financial costs, interaction with workplace safety and health programs, and emerging issues.

name: AH3289
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Provides students in the department of Allied Health Sciences research experience under the guidance and supervision of a department faculty member; designed to engage a student in inquiry and investigation on a topic of interest. Guidelines, learning agreement, and supporting documentation required. Students may only count a maximum combined credit total of six credits toward the Allied Health major of international study, independent study, internship, and research credits.

name: AH3320
prerequisites: BIOL 1107; open only to junior or higher Allied Health majors, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: CHEM 2241 or 2443 and 2444
description: The role of the healthcare professional in dealing with infectious diseases. Epidemiology and public health, healthcare epidemiology, pathogenesis and diagnosing of infectious diseases, overview of the major infectious diseases of humans.

name: AH3570
catalogName: Health and Safety Management in the Workplace
prerequisites: Open only to BGS students and Allied Health Sciences OEHS, Public Health and Health Promotion, or HADM concentration majors juniors or higher, and OSH Certificate students; others with consent.
description: Knowledge and skills necessary to develop a sustainable occupational health and safety management program in the workplace toward the goal of preventing illness and injury, and property damage.

name: AH3571
prerequisites: Open only to BGS students and Allied Health Sciences-OEHS, Public Health and Health Promotion, Standard Plan, and Healthcare Admin concentration majors, juniors or higher, and OSH Certificate students; others with consent. Recommended preparation: AH 2001.
description: Anticipation, recognition, evaluation, control, and communication of health hazards in the workplace.

name: AH3573
catalogName: Health and Safety Standards in the Workplace
prerequisites: Open only to BGS students, Allied Health Sciences-OEHS concentration majors and OSH Certificate students, others with consent; open to juniors or higher.
description: Comprehensive overview of workplace health and safety regulatory processes and standards.

name: AH3574
prerequisites: Open only to BGS students, Allied Health Sciences, and OSH Certificate students, others with consent; open only to juniors or higher.
description: Knowledge and skills for achieving optimal relationships between humans and their work environment.

name: AH4092
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Instruction in basic life support skills, treatment of bleeding control and shock recognition, care for trauma victims, medical emergencies. Supervised practice experience and hands-on instruction of theory. Includes a 10 hour observation experience outside of classroom instruction. Meets the performance requirements of the National Registry of Emergency Medical Technicians (NREMT) certification exam. Students must first register for Hartford Hospital's EMT training program (separate Hartford Hospital program costs apply).

name: AH4093
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Courses taken in Allied Health and related areas as part of an approved Study Abroad Program. May be repeated for credit; may count up to 6 credits toward major with consent of advisor and Department Head. Department Head consent required prior to study abroad. Students may only count a maximum combined credit total of 6 credits toward the Allied Health major of foreign study, Independent Study and Internship credits. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: AH4095
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Investigation of a special topic in allied health related to the basic core or interdisciplinary areas. Credits and hours by arrangement.  May be repeated for credit.

name: AH4239
prerequisites: A course in statistics; open only to Allied Health Sciences majors; others with instructor consent; open to juniors or higher. Corequisite: AH 4240W. Not open for credit to students who have passed AH 4241.
description: Research questions/hypothesis, finding and using research literature, ethical considerations, research design, sampling, measurement, reliability and validity, descriptive and inferential statistics, computer analysis of data, evaluating research, reviews of literature and proposals.

name: AH4240W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; a course in statistics; open to juniors or higher. open only to Allied Health Sciences majors, others with consent of instructor. Corequisite: AH 4239. Not open to students who have passed AH 4241W.
description: Develop scientific writing skills through completing a scientific research proposal.

name: AH4241
prerequisites: A course in statistics; open to juniors or higher; open to Allied Health OEHS concentration majors, Dietetics, DGS, MLS majors, DGS or MLS certificate students (others with consent of instructor). Not open to students who have passed AH 4239.
description: Research questions/hypothesis, finding and using research literature, ethical considerations, research design, sampling, measurement, reliability and validity, descriptive and inferential statistics, computer analysis of data, evaluating research, reviews of literature and proposals.

name: AH4242
catalogName: Counseling and Teaching for the Health Professional
prerequisites: Open to Allied Health Sciences, Dietetics, Medical Technology , Diagnostic Genetic Sciences and Nutritional Sciences majors, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.
description: Learning theory and counseling strategies; role of health professional as teacher and counselor; communicating with special groups, individuals and groups.

name: AH4243
prerequisites: Open to Allied Health Sciences, Dietetics, Medical Laboratory Sci¬ences, Diagnostic Genetic Sciences, Nutritional Sciences and Health Systems Management majors, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.
description: Individual, community and institutional health care needs and issues from a bio-medical and socio-cultural point of view. Health and its relationship to genetics, poverty, ethnicity, life-cycle events, ethics, etc.

name: AH4244
prerequisites: Open to Allied Health Sciences, Dietetics, Medical Technology , Diagnostic Genetic Sciences and Nutritional Sciences majors, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.
description: Basic management principles and concepts of planning, organizing, supervising, controlling and evaluating in health care environments. Leadership, motivation, supervision, time management, labor relations, quality assurance/proficiency, financial management.

name: AH4288
catalogName: Instructional Assistant in Allied Health Sciences
prerequisites: Successful completion of the course to be assisting in with a B grade or better; guidelines, learning agreement, and supporting documentation required; open to juniors or higher with consent of instructor, advisor and department head.
description: Experience with Allied Health Sciences course development and faculty assistance; independent inquiry under the guidance and supervision of an Allied Health Sciences faculty. This course may not be used to meet requirements for the Group A or Group B AHS major requirements. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: AH4289
catalogName: Honors Research in Allied Health Sciences
prerequisites: Open only to Honors students.
description: Provides students in the department of Allied Health Sciences advanced research experience under the guidance and supervision of a department faculty member; designed to engage a student in advanced independent inquiry and investigation on a topic of interest. For students in the Honors program, the understood purpose of the student's involvement in this course is to build toward the completion of an Honors Scholar thesis project. Guidelines, learning agreement, and supporting documentation required. Students may only count a maximum combined credit total of six credits toward the Allied Health major of international study, independent study, internship, and research credits.

name: AH4291
prerequisites: Open only to BGS students, Allied Health Sciences-OEHS concentration majors and OSH Certificate students, others with consent; open to juniors or higher.
description: Application of the principles and concepts of hazard assessment and safety management to an actual workplace under the supervision of an approved onsite supervisor. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 credits applied to the major. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: AH4297W
catalogName: Honors Thesis in Allied Health Sciences
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; instructor consent required. Open only to Department of Allied Health Sciences students, juniors or higher.
description: Completion of written thesis based on student-designed honors research project under supervision of a faculty advisor.

name: AIRF1000
catalogName: Heritage and Values of the United States Air Force
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to the United States Air Force with overview of the basic characteristics, missions, and organization of the Air Force. The two-hour laboratory period is for cadets only.

name: AIRF1200
catalogName: Heritage and Values of the United States Air Force
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History and evolution of the United States Air Force; overview of the Department of the Air Force, its major commands, and an introduction of the principles and tenets of US airpower during warfare. The two-hour laboratory period is for cadets only.

name: AIRF2000
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Foundation for teams and leadership on a personal level and within a team. The two-hour laboratory period is for cadets only.

name: AIRF2200
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Team and leadership fundamentals to include listening, followership, problem solving and conflict management. The two-hour laboratory period is for cadets only.

name: AIRF3000
prerequisites: AIRF 1200 and AIRF 2200, or six weeks field training.
description: Advanced skills and knowledge in management and leadership. Special emphasis on enhancing leadership skills and communication.

name: AIRF3200
prerequisites: AIRF 3000.
description: Advanced skills and knowledge in management and leadership. Special emphasis on enhancing leadership skills and communication.

name: AIRF3500
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Fundamentals of flight, flight operations, aviation, weather, navigation, human factors and integration of pilot skills with Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) regulations.  Meets all requirements for the FAA private pilot's written examination.

name: AIRF4000
catalogName: National Security Affairs/Preparation for Active Duty
prerequisites: AIRF 3000 and AIRF 3200
description: Role of military officers in American society; sophisticated overview of the complex social and political issues facing the military profession.

name: AIRF4200
catalogName: National Security Affairs/Preparation for Active Duty
prerequisites: AIRF 4000; open only with the consent of instructor.
description: Role of military officers in American society; sophisticated overview of the complex social and political issues facing the military profession.

name: AMST1201
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: What is an American?  A multi-disciplinary inquiry into the diversity of American societies and cultures. CA 4.

name: AMST1700
prerequisites: Open to freshmen and sophomores in the Honors Program.
description: Real and imagined landscapes in the Americas as seen through the history of the land and its uses and through changing representations of those landscapes in art, literature, science, and popular culture.  CA 1.

name: AMST2200
catalogName: Literature and Culture of North America before 1800
description: An examination of the early written and oral culture of the area that eventually became the United States. CA 1.

name: AMST2201
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary introduction to major themes in Asian American Studies. Concepts of identity and community, migration and labor histories, Asians and the law, representations of Asians in visual and popular culture, gender issues, interracial and interethnic relations, and human rights. CA 1. CA 4.

name: AMST2204
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Representations of the diversity of Jewish culture (historical, religious, secular) in American film. Introduction to film analysis and interpretation. CA 1. CA 4.

name: AMST2207
description: How the frontier and overseas ambitions have shaped U.S. institutions and culture. The impact of U.S. expansion on people outside its borders. These topics are explored through literary narratives and historical documents. CA 1. CA 4.

name: AMST2274W
catalogName: Disability in American Literature and Culture
description: An interdisciplinary examination of the symbolic roles of disability and the social implications of those roles. CA 1. CA 4.

name: AMST2276
description: Interdisciplinary approaches to American utopian and dystopian literature of the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries. CA 1.

name: AMST2400
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Aesthetics, history, and contemporary relevance of American films that feature the urban, suburban, and/or small town landscape as a major "character" shaping plot and story. Films read closely as texts that make meaning through a range of tools, including narrative, mise-en-scene, editing, camera work, and genre conventions. CA 1.

name: AMST3265W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Interdisciplinary research and writing centered on a specific topic in U.S. culture. An introduction and overview of research methods in American Studies.

name: AMST3281
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: No more than eight credits may be earned in a single placement, and no more than three credits may be counted towards completion of requirements for the American Studies major. Students taking this course will be assigned a grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). May be repeated for credit.

name: AMST3542E
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ENGL 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800.
description: Interdisciplinary history of New England's terrestrial and marine environmental change.  Links among land, sea, and human natural resource use and management, including precontact patterns, colonial impacts, agricultural decline, industrial pollution, overfishing, re-forestation, and the rise of eco-tourism.

name: AMST3568
catalogName: Hip Hop, Politics and Youth Culture in America
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of hip-hop, its musical antecedents and its role in popular culture. Race, class, and gender are examined as well as hip-hop's role in popular political discourse.

name: AMST3570
catalogName: History and Theory of Digital Art
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Investigates forms of digital and Internet art and the mostly forgotten histories of the technologies behind them. Forms and themes to be explored include games/gaming, surveillance art, cyberfeminism, data visualization, and crowdsourced art. CA 1. CA 4.

name: AMST3699
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Supervised reading and writing on a subject of special interest to the student.  May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: AMST3807
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The role of the Supreme Court in interpreting the Bill of Rights. Topics include freedoms of speech and religion, criminal due process, and equal protection.

name: AMST3822
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Exploration of themes in the study of law and courts by contrasting scholarly work against representations of such themes in movies, televisions, and other media of popular culture.

name: AMST4897
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ANSC1001
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The biological, physical, and social factors that influence animal production and utilization.

name: ANSC1111
catalogName: Principles of Animal Nutrition and Feeding
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing ANSC 4311.
description: Digestive anatomy of various species and the classes of nutrients including their digestion, metabolism and sources. Nutrient requirements and feeding standards for livestock, companion animals, exotics and aquatics for purposes of reproduction, lactation, growth, work and maintenance. Classes of feedstuffs, their characteristics, proper utilization, formulating rations and nutritional programs for animal enterprise. Taught with SAAS 113.

name: ANSC1602
catalogName: Behavior and Training of Domestic Animals
prerequisites: Open to Animal Science, Pathobiology and Veterinary Science, Agriculture and Natural Resources majors; others by consent. Recommended preparation: ANSC 1001.
description: Application of behavior of cattle, horses, sheep, goats, swine, poultry, and companion animals to their management, training, and welfare. Basic principles of genetics and physiology of behavior, perception, training, learning, motivation, and stress with consideration of integrated behavioral management and animal welfare. Students are required to have access to an animal that they will train throughout the semester; the Department of Animal Science will not necessarily provide animals for training. Taught concurrently with SAAS 202.

name: ANSC1645
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An introductory level course for students interested in the application of science to food. Nutritional and functional attributes of various food constituents are discussed. Issues concerning food processing and food safety are covered. CA 3.

name: ANSC1676
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Basic concepts of the nutrition, physiology, health and management of companion animals. Taught with SAAS 276.

name: ANSC2251
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing ANSC 3456.
description: Valuable to animal science majors and includes horse types and breeds and their nutrition, breeding, evaluation, behavior, care and management with attention given to detailed studies of the problems and practices of horse production and use. Taught with SAAS 251.

name: ANSC2271
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The application of the basic scientific principles to the management of poultry, egg and meat production systems.

name: ANSC2690
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A multiple day field trip format. Students in this course will travel with the instructor to visit and tour agri-businesses that represent commercial aspects of different animal science activities. Students will interview agri-business personnel and gain an understanding of how agricultural principles are applied in the field. Each student must submit a formal written report for evaluation and meet all other course requirements as specified by the instructor. Field trip is required. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). May be repeated for credit with a change in topic.

name: ANSC2695
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors.  May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: ANSC2699
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: ANSC3121
prerequisites: BIOL 1108; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1107.
description: Principles of Mendelian and molecular genetics. Biosynthesis and function of DNA, RNA, and protein. This course also includes introductions to population and quantitative genetics. Information on molecular methods of genetic analysis and examples of genetics in animals of agricultural significance are also provided.

name: ANSC3122
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A study of the reproductive anatomy and physiology of domestic animals. Laboratory will include macro and micro anatomy, hormone action, and techniques used in reproductive management of domestic animals.

name: ANSC3194
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: A discussion of current employment opportunities in animal agriculture.  In addition, students will prepare resumes and make oral presentation.

name: ANSC3261
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Management of dairy cattle including milking procedures, sanitation, selection, nutrition, reproduction, physiology and anatomy of milk secretion and record keeping. Field trips required. Taught with SAAS 261.

name: ANSC3272
prerequisites: BIOL 1107.  Recommended preparation:  BIOL 1108 or equivalent.
description: Principles and practices of laboratory animal care and management in relation to animal characteristics, handling and restraint, animal house design, reproduction and nutrition and legal regulations. Various laboratory animal techniques will be covered.

name: ANSC3273
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The production and management of beef cattle, sheep, and swine. Laboratories involve theory and practice in livestock management, skills, and techniques. Taught with SAAS 273.

name: ANSC3311
prerequisites: PVS 2100 or PNB 2265 or 2275; open to juniors or higher.
description: A comparative study of the effects of exercise on the body, focusing on the three primary athletic species (canine, equine, human). Particular emphasis will be placed on the physiological mechanisms which allow for adaptation to exercise and inactivity.

name: ANSC3312W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Comparative Exercise Physiology
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800; open to juniors and higher. Co-requisite: ANSC 3311
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3311.

name: ANSC3313
catalogName: Growth Biology and Metabolism in Domestic Livestock
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.  Recommended preparation: PVS 2100.
description: Focuses on the embryonic and postnatal growth and development of domestic livestock with emphasis on metabolic and hormonal regulation of processes that influence growth and development. Discussion period will focus on methods used to measure growth and metabolism.

name: ANSC3314W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Growth Biology and Metabolism of Domestic Livestock
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; must be taken concurrently with ANSC 3313; open to juniors or higher.
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3313.

name: ANSC3316
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.  Recommended preparation: PVS 2100 or equivalent.
description: Focuses on endocrine systems and endocrine function in farm animals with emphasis on hormones involved in metabolism, growth, lactation, feed intake and digestion in cattle, pigs, horses and poultry.

name: ANSC3317W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Endocrinology of Farm Animals
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; Open to juniors or higher. Corequisite: ANSC 3316
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3316, Endocrinology of Farm Animals.

name: ANSC3318
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: MCB 2610 or equivalent (can be taken concurrently)
description: Biology, uses, effectiveness and safety of probiotics and prebiotics. Molecular mechanisms underlying the health benefits attributed to the consumption of pre and probiotics. Application of pre- and probiotics to promote human and animal health, including safety and regulation.

name: ANSC3323
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.   Recommended preparation: ANSC 3122 or MCB 4219.
description: Introduction to recent research in animal embryology and related reproductive biotechnologies. Basic principles, methodology and state of the technology for numerous established and emerging animal biotechnologies such as transgenesis and cloning.

name: ANSC3324W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher. Corequisite: ANSC 3323.
description: Writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3323 Animal Embryology and Embryo Biotechnology.

name: ANSC3343
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: A study of the food products derived from animal agriculture, including dairy, meat, poultry and fish. Emphasis will be placed on inspection, grading, processing, biochemistry, nutritive value and food safety concerns of these products. Taught with SAAS 243.

name: ANSC3344W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Animal Food Products
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; must be taken concurrently with ANSC 3343; open to juniors or higher.
description: A writing-intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3343.

name: ANSC3452
prerequisites: ANSC 2251.  Open to juniors or higher.
description: Designed to develop technical and managerial skills necessary for operating horse breeding farms. Programs for herd health, hoof care, nutrition, breeding, foaling, and record keeping will be included.

name: ANSC3453
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed ANSC 3456.
description: Open to all University students interested in pleasure horses. The principles of horse management and horsemanship.

name: ANSC3455
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Techniques related to training the driving horse will be described. Prior working experience with horses is recommended.

name: ANSC3456
prerequisites: ANSC 2251.
description: The theory, fundamentals and practice of breaking, training, fitting, showing, and the use of horses for riding. Primarily for Animal Science majors.

name: ANSC3457
prerequisites: ANSC 3452; instructor consent required.
description: Management of the pregnant mare and neonatal foal, including foaling practices, foal handling, and postpartum care of the mare.

name: ANSC3641
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Production and processing of milk and milk-products from a food science perspective including chemical, physical and microbiological components. Technological aspects of the transformation of milk into various food products. Public health regulations, good manufacturing practices, cleaning and sanitizing procedures. Unit operations in dairy food manufacturing, packaging, labeling and quality control procedures.

name: ANSC3642W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Animal Food Products: Dairy Technology
prerequisites: ANSC 3641, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800.
description: A writing intensive course integrated with course content in ANSC 3641.

name: ANSC3663
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Participation in all phases of dairy herd management including decision-making activities, with particular emphasis on impact of decisions on financial health and stability. Course requires participation beyond specific semester calendars. May be repeated twice for credit.

name: ANSC3664
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: An introduction to the evaluation of dairy cattle on the basis of conformation. Breed classification and type improvement programs, score card criteria in relation to longevity, physiological efficiency and performance are included. Attention is also given to fitting and showing methods. Field trips may be required.

name: ANSC3674
prerequisites: Not open for credit to graduate students.
description: Classification, form to function relationships, grades and value differences of livestock are included. Objective and subjective methods of appraisal are used to evaluate beef cattle, horses, sheep and swine. Taught with SAAS 274.

name: ANSC3675
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.  Not open for credit to graduate students
description: Intensive training in the evaluation of selected species of farm animals or their products. Type standards and the relation of anatomical features to physiological function are emphasized. Evaluation skills including justification of decisions will be developed. Intercollegiate dairy cattle, horse, livestock, poultry judging teams will be selected from this course. Field trips are required, some of which may occur prior to the start of the semester.  May be repeated once for credit. Taught with SAAS 275.

name: ANSC3691
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). Credits and hours by arrangement.

name: ANSC3693
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Variable topics. May be repeated for credit.

name: ANSC3695
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Credits and hours by arrangement.  May be repeated for credit with a change of topic. Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors.

name: ANSC4311
prerequisites: ANSC 1111; open to juniors or higher.
description: A comparative study of nutritional, physiological, microbiological, immunological and biochemical aspects of digestion and metabolism in the non-ruminant and ruminant animal, particularly livestock and companion animals. Topics include digestive system structures, utilization of nutrients, energy metabolism, control of nutrient metabolism, and experimental techniques used in the study of animal nutrition.

name: ANSC4312W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Advanced Animal Nutrition
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher. Corequisite: ANSC 4311.
description: Writing-intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 4311.

name: ANSC4341
prerequisites: Biology 1107;  open to junior or higher.  Recommended preparation: a one semester course in organic chemistry.
description: Current topics in food safety will be discussed, with special emphasis on microbial and chemical contamination of food. Specific topics including the safety of natural versus synthetic chemicals, food additives, irradiation and other practices, basic microbiology and toxicology, current regulatory practices and risk assessment will also be included. The Hazard Analysis Critical Control Points (HACCP) approach to food safety will be discussed.

name: ANSC4342W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Food Microbiology and Safety
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800; open to juniors or higher. Corequisite: ANSC 4341
description: A writing-intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 4341.

name: ANSC4457
prerequisites: Intermediate II or above riding experience required.
description: The techniques and procedures of teaching equitation including the theories of riding and teaching methods. Practice teaching will be required under the supervision of the instructor. Taught with SAAS 257.

name: ANSC4662W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; ANSC 3261; open to juniors or higher.
description:
Dairy farm management practices with emphasis on business and economic decision making. The effects of various programs in selection, nutrition, facilities, reproduction and herd health on overall business health will be evaluated. Each student will manage a computer simulated herd during the semester.  Field trips are required.
GEOC;

name: ANSC4697W
catalogName: Undergraduate Honors Thesis Writing in Animal Science
prerequisites: Three credits of ANSC 2699 or 5692, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Writing of a formal thesis based on independent research conducted by the student. Thesis proposal and final thesis must follow guidelines developed by the department.

name: ANTH1000
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: An introduction to the anthropological understanding of human society through ethnographic case studies of selected peoples and cultures, exploring the richness and variety of human life. Encourages students to learn about different cultures and to apply their knowledge to make sense of their own society. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1000
catalogName: Peoples and Cultures of the World
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: An introduction to the anthropological understanding of human society through ethnographic case studies of selected peoples and cultures, exploring the richness and variety of human life. Encourages students to learn about different cultures and to apply their knowledge to make sense of their own society. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1000W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: An introduction to the anthropological understanding of human society through ethnographic case studies of selected peoples and cultures, exploring the richness and variety of human life. Encourages students to learn about different cultures and to apply their knowledge to make sense of their own society. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1000W
catalogName: Peoples and Cultures of the World
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: An introduction to the anthropological understanding of human society through ethnographic case studies of selected peoples and cultures, exploring the richness and variety of human life. Encourages students to learn about different cultures and to apply their knowledge to make sense of their own society. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1006
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: The biological and cultural development of humans from their origin to the present. A brief survey of human evolution is followed by a comparative study of behavior and beliefs of our own and other societies. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1010E
catalogName: Global Climate Change and Human Societies
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A multidisciplinary examination of the nature, anthropogenic drivers, range of expressions, and impacts of contemporary and future global climate change as well as cultural understandings of this significant environmental process and diverse human responses to it. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1500
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of important discoveries in archaeology spanning the whole of human prehistory across the globe. Current issues, methods, and techniques in the field of archaeology. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH2000
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing ANTH 4001.
description: A comparative study of social structure including an analysis of kinship, marriage, community organization, political and economic institutions, and the role of the individual in these institutions.  CA 2. CA 4.

name: ANTH2000W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Not open to students who have passed ANTH 4001.
description: A comparative study of social structure including an analysis of kinship, marriage, community organization, political and economic institutions, and the role of the individual in these institutions. CA 2. CA 4.

name: ANTH2501
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing ANTH 3521 or 3704.
description: The concepts, methods and practice of anthropological archaeology.

name: ANTH2502
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The processes and events leading to the origin of human beings. Human physical and cultural development from its beginning to the dawn of settled life, through the approaches of physical anthropology and archaeology.

name: ANTH2600
description: Introduction to research trends in archaeobotany and use of microscopy tools. Design and execution of a research project. CA 3-LAB.

name: ANTH3003
prerequisites: ANTH 1000 or 1006.
description: Methods and techniques of field research in social settings, including observational procedures, interviewing, and the construction and use of questionnaires.

name: ANTH3004
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The theoretical foundations and basic methods used to collect and analyze cultural data.

name: ANTH3021
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of anthropological contributions to the study of contemporary Mexico, Central America, South America, and the Hispanic Caribbean. Special focus on the comparative analysis of recent ethnographic case studies and local/regional/national/international linkages.

name: ANTH3027
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Analysis of Native American reservations and urban communities and their relationship to the larger U.S. society. Special focus on federal policy and economic development, cultural identity, and  politics of Native Americans.

name: ANTH3028
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ANTH 2000.
description: An introduction to the study and understanding of Aboriginal ways of life and thought. An exploration of the complexity of contemporary indigenous social orders and land rights issues. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH3028W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: ANTH 2000.
description: An introduction to the study and understanding of Aboriginal ways of life and thought. An exploration of the complexity of contemporary indigenous social orders and land rights issues. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH3029
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Comparative perspectives on the cultural formation of Caribbean societies; the region's demographic, economic and political links with the wider world.

name: ANTH3030
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of the indigenous societies and cultures of the Pacific Islands, from the first settlement to the postcolonial period. Topics include prehistoric canoe voyaging, modes of subsistence, political forms, ritual and religion, ceremonial exchange, gender ideologies, European colonization, and modern indigenous nationalism. Ethnographic examples will be drawn from Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH3093
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor. May be repeated for credit.

name: ANTH3098
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: Prerequisites, required preparation, and reccomended preparation vary.  With a change of topic,  may be repeated for credit.

name: ANTH3099
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change of content, may be repeated for credit.

name: ANTH3120
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Ethnographic approaches to classic and contemporary debates about capitalism's transformation of sociocultural dynamics.

name: ANTH3150
prerequisites: Recomended preparation: ANTH 1000 or 1006.
description: The social, cultural and economic causes and consequences of internal and international migration in the modern era. Topics include migrant selection, social adaptation, effects on home and host societies, and cultural identity. CA 4.

name: ANTH3150W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: ANTH 1000 or 1006.
description: The social, cultural and economic causes and consequences of internal and international migration in the modern era. Topics include migrant selection, social adaptation, effects on home and host societies, and cultural identity. CA 4.

name: ANTH3152
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Popular and scholarly theories of human group identity and diversity, in cross-cultural and historical perspective. Topics include: an overview of 'race' and 'ethnicity' in Western thought, ethnic group formation and transformation, political mobilizations of group identity, and systems of inequality. CA 2. CA 4.

name: ANTH3200
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The application of the theory of natural selection to the study of human culture and behavior, with emphasis on the interaction between humans and their environment.

name: ANTH3202W
description: Cross-cultural analysis of ethnomedicine, major medical systems, alternative medical systems, curing and healing illness and social control, gender and healing, and the role of traditional and cosmopolitan medical systems in international health. CA 4.

name: ANTH3230
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed ANTH 3098 when offered as Propaganda, Fake News and Hate Speech
description: Draws on current social science research to understand the effects of false information and hate speech on our politics and culture and to evaluate various private and public initiatives to regulate speech. CA 2.

name: ANTH3250
prerequisites: Recommended preparation:  ANTH 3002.
description: The study of how the content of thought or knowledge is created, organized, and distributed in human communities. Topics include cultural models of the mind, emotions, personality, and relationships.

name: ANTH3251
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Cross-cultural overview of critical issues regarding the relationship between individual personality and sociocultural systems, and mental health and illness.

name: ANTH3326
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Theories, methods and controversies in the interconnected fields of global health and human rights.

name: ANTH3340E
description: Interdisciplinary analysis of conservation and the human-environment relationship from a cross-cultural perspective. Major topics include sustainability, environmental ethics, climate change, natural disasters, health, and environmental justice. CA2. CA4-INT.

name: ANTH3350
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Major conceptual and historical problems in the study of gender in anthropology. Women's roles in different historical and contemporary settings, and new understandings of family, kinship, power, and cultural ideologies.

name: ANTH3400
prerequisites: ANTH 1000 or 1006.
description: Major theories and approaches in the study of religion as a social institution and cultural system. Topics include myth, ritual, taboos and pollution beliefs, shamanism, magical practices, fundamentalism and religion in modern society.

name: ANTH3401
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A survey of religious belief systems, both polytheistic and monotheistic, from around the world. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH3403
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Gender issues in the world's religions. Survey of women's theological standing, ritual activities and participation in a cross-cultural sample of religions, both monotheistic and polytheistic.

name: ANTH3506W
description: The analysis, interpretation, and presentation of archaeological data sets including lithics, ceramics, floral and faunal remains and spatial information from excavated sites.

name: ANTH3512
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An archaeological perspective on more than three million years of human social and behavioral change in Africa, from Stone Age societies that are the earliest in the world to sweeping changes brought about by the development and spread of cattle and crops, sophisticated metallurgy, and the later rise of kingdoms and complex polities situated at a global crossroads of trade and interaction.

name: ANTH3514
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary survey of the archaeological, biological, cultural, and behavioral evolution of prehistoric humans and their societies across Europe and portions of western Asia.

name: ANTH3523
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The origins and spread of agriculture worldwide. Economic, social and ideological ramifications of the agricultural transition. Processes of plant and animal domestication.

name: ANTH3531
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ANTH 1500, ANTH 2501, ANTH 2510 or HIST 3544.
description: Archaeological and historical sources to examine the development of seafaring practices, exploration, waterborne trade and economic systems, naval warfare and shipbuilding in the Americas from the fifteenth to the beginning of the twentieth century.

name: ANTH3555
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Survey of scientific methods used to answer archaeological questions. Methods, applications and lab demonstrations.

name: ANTH3703
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Method and theory of archaeological faunal analysis, including training in the identification of skeletal materials, the formation of the zooarchaeological record, and  the interpretation of zooarchaeological data.

name: ANTH3705
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ANTH 2501, 2502 or 3503.
