description: Parent behavior and the dynamics of parenthood; interpersonal, familial, and societal roles of parents and variables influencing these roles across the lifespan. CA 2.

name: HDFS3319
catalogName: Risk and Resilience in Individuals and Families
prerequisites: HDFS 2300; open to juniors or higher.
description: Challenges, stresses, and crises experienced by individuals and families; protective factors and resilience; coping strategies; prevention and intervention.

name: HDFS3340
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.  Recommended preparation: HDFS 2300.
description: An introduction to individual, couple, family, and group intervention. Topics include counseling theories, developmentally appropriate interventions, and methods for addressing diversity. Intervention strategies used in a variety of human services settings are examined.

name: HDFS3342
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Decision-making process of families concerning the utilization of financial, personal, environmental and social resources.

name: HDFS3343
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Theory and practice of family life education including program development, implementation, evaluation, and professional ethics.

name: HDFS3421
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Impact of poverty and related problems on development of the child in the context of the family. Family structure, childrearing patterns, early educational and community programs.

name: HDFS3423
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Pre-industrial and industrial family life in Western society since the Middle Ages, with emphasis on the changes in demography, family size and structure, family economy, social expectations, sex roles, sexuality, and affective bonds.

name: HDFS3425
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: HDFS 2004W; PSYC 2100WQ, or equivalent research methods course.
description: Comprehensive and critical examination of how individual characteristics, family factors, community environments, food industry actions, and government food policies work together to influence what Americans eat throughout the lifespan.

name: HDFS3430
prerequisites: HDFS 1070 or 2100 or PSYC 2400; open to juniors or higher.
description: The role of families in the education process. The effective family-school-community partnership in educating children: Communications and the implications of culture, socio-economics, family form, family dynamics, family supports, and public policy.

name: HDFS3442
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Overview of health and health care issues among Latinos in the United States.  Particular attention is paid to cultural and social factors associated with health and well being (e.g. migration, acculturation, SES).

name: HDFS3510
catalogName: Planning and Managing Human Service Programs
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Planning techniques: needs assessment, data collection and analysis, budgeting, and evaluation. Management skills: decision making, management theory and organizational behavior, personnel motivation, accountability, and financial management.

name: HDFS3520
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Overview of historical roots and key aspects of family law.  The case method is used to analyze the causes and effects of contemporary trends.  Topics include: the regulation of marriage, separation, and divorce; procreation and abortion; adoption; child custody and support; and, end-of-life issues.

name: HDFS3530
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Analysis of government programs and policies impacting the family: child care, aging, family law, mental health, family violence, income maintenance, and family impact analysis.

name: HDFS3540W
catalogName: Child Welfare, Law and Social Policy
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HDFS3550
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Comparative analysis of government programs and policies impacting families in the United States and other countries. Health and welfare policies, family planning, child care, teen pregnancy, and care of the aged.

name: HDFS4004
prerequisites: HDFS 2004; 12 credits of 2000-level or above HDFS courses; open only to Human Development and Family Sciences majors.
description: Students will work as a research team to conduct a research project through all of its phases, from formulating a research question to final presentation of findings.

name: HDFS4007W
prerequisites: HDFS 2004; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; 12 additional credits of 2000 level or above HDFS courses; open to HDFS majors.
description: Development of advanced written and oral communication skills required for professional careers and graduate studies. Emphasis is placed on appropriate presentation and writing styles for the diverse audiences and purposes encountered in research and practice.

name: HDFS4087W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to students in the Honors Program only.
description: Individual study with student's honors thesis supervisor for the purpose of writing the honors thesis. Student must have a thesis advisor and have an approved thesis topic.

name: HDFS4097
prerequisites: HDFS 3087; open students in the Honors Program with instructor consent.  May be repeated to a maximum of four credits.
description: Prepares students to tackle the honors thesis by covering the basics of the thesis process. Course content will focus on strategies to make the thesis manageable, organizational and writing skills, and discussion of seminar members'  thesis projects and progress. In this seminar, students form a community of scholars to discuss and support each other's work. May be repeated for credit.

name: HDFS4099
prerequisites: HDFS 2004.
description: Students, working with a faculty supervisor, develop plans for an independent research project or review paper, execute the project, and complete a report. May be taken more than one semester.

name: HDFS4181W
catalogName: Early Childhood Development and Education: Supervised Teaching Practicum
description: Supervised teaching experience within the Child Development Labs or approved early education center. Development of advanced written and oral communication skills required for early childhood educators with emphasis on appropriate presentation and writing styles for diverse audiences.

name: HDFS4182
catalogName: Administration and Leadership in Early Childhood Programs: Practicum
prerequisites: HDFS 4181 and a GPA of 2.5 in HDFS courses; open to juniors or higher.
description: Continuation of HDFS 4181. Experience in early childhood program implementation, administration, staff supervising, policy making, and curriculum planning.

name: HEJS1003
prerequisites: HEJS 1002 or the equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HEJS 1004. May not be taken for credit after passing HEJS 3251.
description: Building on first-year skills, more advanced grammar, vocabulary, and conversation. Examples from popular media and culture along with short readings continue to enhance students' language acquisition. Formerly offered as HEJS 1153.

name: HEJS1103
catalogName: Who Are the Jews? Jewish Identity through the Ages
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The major concepts, personalities and literary works that inform Jewish identity from the Biblical and Talmudic periods to the present. Taught in English.CA 1. CA 4.

name: HEJS1151
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HEJS1152
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HEJS1153
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HEJS1154
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HEJS2200
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Major themes in Zionist and Israeli history and the development of Israeli art, literature, film, popular music, dance, theater, and popular culture, with a focus on the central questions that have both unified and divided Israeli society and politics. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HEJS2203
catalogName: The Holocaust in Print, Theater, and Film
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Representations of the Holocaust, including first-hand accounts and documentaries; artistic choices in genre, structure, imagery, point of view, and the limits of representation. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HEJS2204
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Representations of the diversity of Jewish culture (historical, religious, secular) in American film. Introduction to film analysis and interpretation. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HEJS2301
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed HEJS 3295 when taught as this topic
description: The history of Jewish humor in modern times with attention given to its various forms, including oral traditions, fiction and humor writing, stand-up comedy, live performance, television, film, and music. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HEJS3203
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Origins, development, and legacy of the Holocaust. Topics include the history of modern European anti-Semitism, the creation of the Nazi state, the catalytic role of the Second World War, the actions and attitudes of the perpetrators, victims, and bystanders, and the diverse ways in which scholars and societies have dealt with the legacy of the Holocaust. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement.

name: HEJS3251
prerequisites: HEJS 1004 or instructor consent.
description: Further grammar study. Practice in composition involving the use of everyday vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. Readings and films relevant to Israeli culture and history.   With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HEJS3252
prerequisites: HEJS 3251
description: Further grammar study. Practice in composition involving the use of everyday vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. Readings and films relevant to Israeli culture and history.   With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HEJS3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program.  May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: HEJS3301
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of sacred and secular literature in a wide variety of genres produced by Jews in the medieval period from major centers of European settlement. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HEJS3330
catalogName: Palestine Under the Greeks and Romans
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The political, historical and religious currents in Greco-Roman Palestine. Includes the Jewish Revolts, sectarian developments, the rise of Christianity and the Talmudic academies. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Taught in English. Formerly offered as HEJS 3218.

name: HEJS3362
catalogName: The Black Death: Medieval and Modern Responses to Catastrophe
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed HEJS 3295 when offered as The Black Death: Medieval Responses
description: The Black Death (1346-50) from its origins in China through Europe. Institutional, medical, religious, literary, and social responses to the plague; how modern scholars reconstruct medieval experience; and new findings by historians and scientists that shed light on the challenges of past, present and future pandemics. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HEJS3401
description: Interdisciplinary study of literary and artistic productions by and about Jews in the United States. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIND1101
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing HIND 1102, 1103, or 1104.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Hindi, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.

name: HIND1102
prerequisites: HIND 1101 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HIND 1103 or 1104.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Hindi, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic survival needs within a cultural setting.

name: HIND1103
prerequisites: HIND 1102 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HIND 1104.
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Hindi within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Hindi-speaking world.

name: HIND1104
prerequisites: HIND 1103 or equivalent.
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Hindi within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Hindi-speaking world.

name: HIND1193
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST1100
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Uses historical documents focusing on a single incident in the past to reconstruct what happened and why.  Emphasizes development of historical research skills such as evaluating evidence, explaining cause and effect, and understanding events in their larger social, political, cultural, and economic contexts. CA 1.

name: HIST1100W
description: Uses historical documents focusing on a single incident in the past to reconstruct what happened and why.  Emphasizes development of historical research skills such as evaluating evidence, explaining cause and effect, and understanding events in their larger social, political, cultural, and economic contexts. CA 1.

name: HIST1201
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: A survey of the historical experiences of the world's major civilizations during recent centuries with particular attention to the modernization of the traditional cultures of Asia, Latin America, and Africa. CA 1.

name: HIST1203
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The historical roots of challenges faced by contemporary women as revealed in the Western and/or non-Western experience: the political, economic, legal, religious, intellectual and family life of women. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST1206
catalogName: Living Through War in World History Since 1500
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Experiences and perceptions of both military and civilian participants in different kinds of wars around the world over the past 500 years. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1300
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An analysis of the traditions and changes which have shaped Western political institutions, economic systems, social structures and culture in ancient and medieval times. CA 1.

name: HIST1400
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of political institutions, economic systems, social structures, and cultures in the modern Western world. CA 1.

name: HIST1501
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history through the Civil War and Reconstruction. CA 1.

name: HIST1501W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history through the Civil War and Reconstruction. CA 1.

name: HIST1502
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history from 1877 to the present. CA 1.

name: HIST1502W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history from 1877 to the present. CA 1.

name: HIST1503
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: What is an American?  A multi-disciplinary inquiry into the diversity of American societies and cultures. CA 4.

name: HIST1570
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary honors course on the life and work experiences of contemporary Latin American and Caribbean migrant workers with focus on Connecticut. Integrated service learning component. Field trips required. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST1600
catalogName: Introduction to Latin America and the Caribbean
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Multidisciplinary exploration of the historical development of such aspects of Latin America and the Caribbean as colonization and nation formation; geography and the environment; immigration and migration; race, ethnicity, and gender in society, politics, economy, and culture. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1800
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A survey of the early development and staying power of the traditional cultures from which the major societies of modern Asia have evolved. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1801
catalogName: History of Asia in the World to 1500
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Development and spread of the Indic and Sinitic civilizations to 1500, with attention to cross-cultural contacts and sources of historical knowledge. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1993
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Credits and hours by arrangement. Open only with consent of department head, Normally granted before the student's departure. May be repeated for credit.

name: HIST2020
catalogName: Pyramids, Pirates, and the Polis: The Ancient Mediterranean
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Political and intellectual history of the civilizations that emerged around the ancient Mediterranean, including the Near East, Egypt, Greece, and Rome, with emphasis on their interactions and influences. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST2100
prerequisites: Open only to history majors. May not be taken out of sequence after passing passing HIST 4996 or 4997.
description: Learning critical reading, thinking and writing skills by interpreting a variety of primary sources.

name: HIST2206
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Development of modern science and technology in relation to culture, politics, and social issues.  CA 1.

name: HIST2207
description: How the frontier and overseas ambitions have shaped U.S. institutions and culture. The impact of U.S. expansion on people outside its borders. These topics are explored through literary narratives and historical documents. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST2210
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST2222E
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Transformations of the global environment since 1450: the effects of human practices and ideas, especially on energy, landscapes, and commodities. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST2240
catalogName: History of War in the Modern World
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.
description: Selected topics analyzing the interactions of warfare, military theories and practice with social, economic and technological developments since 1815.

name: HIST2401W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.
description: Examines the Restoration, the mid-century revolutions, and the forces of nationalism, liberalism and imperialism. New social and economic movements and currents of thought are described and explored. CA 1.

name: HIST2402
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.
description: Twentieth Century Europe and its world relationships in the era of two world wars, the great depression, and the cold war. CA 1.

name: HIST2402W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.
description: Twentieth Century Europe and its world relationships in the era of two world wars, the great depression, and the cold war. CA 1.

name: HIST2530
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of Asian American experiences in the United States since 1850.  Responses by Asian Americans to both opportunities and discrimination.

name: HIST2832
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Examines the dawn of the modern era to the present day in a place we call Japan. In each of our readings, we will seek to understand what constitutes, as one scholar put it, "history versus the radiant myth of belonging."

name: HIST2993
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Consent of department head required, normally granted before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of advisor. May be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3098
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section
description: With a change of topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3101W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: What classic novels and other works of fiction reveal about major historical periods and themes in history. Variable topics. May be offered from an American or European perspective. With a change in topic, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3102
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to the field of public history; in-depth study and practice of one selected topic in public history, such as exhibit design, oral history, institutional history, or archive management. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3201
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Case studies in the emergence and evolution of human rights as experience and  concept.

name: HIST3202
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Historical and theoretical survey of the evolution of human rights since 1945.

name: HIST3203
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3204W
catalogName: Science and Social Issues in the Modern World
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Social context of science in the United States and Europe since 1850. Genetics and eugenics; ecology and the environment; nuclear issues; gender, race, and science. CA 4.

name: HIST3205
catalogName: Personality and Power in the Twentieth Century
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3206
description: Major themes in recent scholarship of African-descended communities in the Americas and their interconnection beyond geopolitical boundaries; race, gender, sexuality, class, religion, cultural movements and practices, slavery, political economy, political movements, and African consciousness, from historical perspective. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3232
catalogName: History of Refugees, Migration, and Statelessness
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Forced and voluntary migration and statelessness in the era of the modern state. Topics include the social and political factors influencing population movement; the experience of migration and statelessness; rights of refugees, migrants, and the stateless; immigration policy; international action; and social and political responses to migration.

name: HIST3320
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of Greece from Minoan and Mycenaean times until the Hellenistic Period and Alexander the Great, with special emphasis on the Fifth Century and the "Golden Age" of Athens.

name: HIST3321
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The Eastern Mediterranean (the Greek east) from Alexander to Cleopatra (336-30 BCE), including historical, cultural, social, and religious developments.

name: HIST3325
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: From the beginning of Rome to the growth of the Roman Republic and the onset of Empire. Roman civilization and its influence upon later history.

name: HIST3330
catalogName: Palestine Under the Greeks and Romans
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The political, historical and religious currents in Greco-Roman Palestine. Includes the Jewish Revolts, sectarian developments, the rise of Christianity and the Talmudic academies. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Taught in English. Formerly offered as HEJS 3218.

name: HIST3360
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of the medieval West from late antiquity to the eleventh century.

name: HIST3361
catalogName: The High and Later Middle Ages
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of the medieval West from the tenth to the fifteenth centuries.

name: HIST3362
catalogName: The Black Death: Medieval and Modern Responses to Catastrophe
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed HEJS 3295 when offered as The Black Death: Medieval Responses
description: The Black Death (1346-50) from its origins in China through Europe. Institutional, medical, religious, literary, and social responses to the plague; how modern scholars reconstruct medieval experience; and new findings by historians and scientists that shed light on the challenges of past, present and future pandemics. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3416
catalogName: Gender and Sexuality in Modern Europe
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The construction of gender difference and ideas about sexuality in western Europe since 1789. Masculinity and femininity; sexuality, identity and the state; European power and personhood in global context.

name: HIST3418
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Origins, development, and legacy of the Holocaust. Topics include the history of modern European anti-Semitism, the creation of the Nazi state, the catalytic role of the Second World War, the actions and attitudes of the perpetrators, victims, and bystanders, and the diverse ways in which scholars and societies have dealt with the legacy of the Holocaust. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement.

name: HIST3421
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3440
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The disintegration of the monarchical synthesis prior to and during the French Revolution; the attempts to harmonize French society under subsequent regimes.

name: HIST3460
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Italy from the triumph of the city-state and the popolo grosso to the end of the Renaissance. The complex interrelationship between society and culture will be the focus of study.

name: HIST3463
catalogName: The Modernization of Italy from 1815 to Present
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The modernization of Italy's traditional sociopolitical and economic structure; Industrialization, unification, the liberal regime, fascism, and the republic.

name: HIST3502
catalogName: Colonial America: Native Americans, Slaves, and Settlers, 1492-1760
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The legacy of Columbus, creative survival of native Americans in the face of disease and warfare, religious utopianism and the profit motive in colonization.  The growth of a distinctive Anglo-American political culture, gender and family relations, and the entrenchment of a racial caste system.

name: HIST3504
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Creation of the United States of America from the beginnings of the independence movement through the adoption of the Constitution and Bill of Rights.

name: HIST3510
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The social, economic and cultural forces that shaped the Civil War and its aftermath. Sectional conflict, industrialization, reform and abolitionism, race relations, and class, gender and constitutional issues from the 1830s to the 1880s.

name: HIST3516
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The people and ideas that powered the growth of America's global empire.  Emphasis on the world wars, the Cold War, the Vietnam War, intervention in Latin America, and the global economy.

name: HIST3531
catalogName: Japanese Americans and World War II
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The events leading to martial law and executive order 9066, the wartime experience of Japanese Americans, and national consequences. Formerly offered as AASI 3531. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST3541
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3541W
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3542
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3542E
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ENGL 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800.
description: Interdisciplinary history of New England's terrestrial and marine environmental change.  Links among land, sea, and human natural resource use and management, including precontact patterns, colonial impacts, agricultural decline, industrial pollution, overfishing, re-forestation, and the rise of eco-tourism.

name: HIST3544
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Late medieval and early modern European expansion into the Atlantic and Indian oceans, with particular attention to European, Asian, African, and American contexts within which that expansion took place. Topics include the transatlantic slave trade; technology adoption and adaptation; convergence of trade, racial ideology, imperial expansion, and imperial identity construction; piracy and settlement; historiographical legacies and later imperialism; and decolonization of contemporary understandings.

name: HIST3556W
catalogName: History Workshop: Topics in American Society and Culture
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Techniques of primary historical research based on collaborative research and writing on a topic selected by the instructor. With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3559
catalogName: History of Childhood in the United States, 1620-Present
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 1501 or 1502 or 2100.
description: An overview of the history of childhood in America, examining both adults' perception and children's experience. Attention to changes in childhood over time and to the diversity of childhood within each historical moment.

name: HIST3560
catalogName: Constructions of Race, Gender, and Sexuality in U.S. History
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed HIST 3095 when taught as Constructions of Race, Gender, and Sexuality in U.S. History.
description: Examination of historical development, interconnections, and complexities of conceptions of race, gender, and sexuality in U.S. from European conquest to the present.

name: HIST3562
catalogName: History of Women and Gender in the United States, 1850-Present
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of gender and the lives and cultural representations of women in the U.S., emphasizing intersections with race, sexuality, class, region, and nation.

name: HIST3563
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of African-American people to 1865, from their West African roots, to their presence in colonial America, through enslavement and emancipation. Adaptation and resistance to their conditions in North America. Contributions by black people to the development of the United States.

name: HIST3564
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of African-American people since the Civil war. Contributions by black people to American development. African-American activity in international arenas.

name: HIST3568
catalogName: Hip Hop, Politics and Youth Culture in America
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of hip-hop, its musical antecedents and its role in popular culture. Race, class, and gender are examined as well as hip-hop's role in popular political discourse.

name: HIST3570
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3575
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Latino/a issues related to human, civil and cultural rights, and gender differences.

name: HIST3607
catalogName: Latin America in the Colonial Period
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Pre-Columbian Civilization in America, the epoch of conquest and settlement, together with a study of the Ibero-Indian cultural synthesis which forms the basis of modern Latin American civilization. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3609
catalogName: Latin America in the National Period
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Representative countries in North, Central, and South America and the Caribbean together with the historic development of inter-American relations and contemporary Latin American problems. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3618
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The rise and fall of trans-Atlantic slavery. Topics include resistance, migration, antislavery mobilization, abolitionism, empire, revolution, cultural production, political economy, labor, gender, race and identity formation.

name: HIST3622
catalogName: History of Gender and Sexuality in Latin America and the Caribbean
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Topics may include: empire and colonialism/anti-colonialism; slavery, science, and the state; cultural practices and institutions; feminisms and masculinities; law and public policies; immigration; forms of labor and political mobilization; sex and reproduction; and human rights from historical perspective.

name: HIST3635
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 3607.
description: The emergence of modern Mexico from independence to the present with emphasis on the Revolution of 1910. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3650
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3674
catalogName: History of Latinos/as in the United States
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Settlement and growth of Hispanic-origin populations in the United States today, from Spanish and Mexican settlement of the western United States to the growth of Latino communities. Student oral history project. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST3704
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 1300 or 1400.
description: The social dynamics of faith, culture, and change from the rise of Islam to the Ottoman decline and the Islamic challenge to Greek and Latin Christendom.

name: HIST3705
catalogName: The Modern Middle East from 1700 to the Present
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Tradition, change, modernization and development in the Middle East from the Ottoman decline and rise of successor states to the Arab-Israeli and oil crises. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3712
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Twentieth-century issues in the Middle East heartland with analysis focusing on the Ottoman heritage, nationalism, Arab-Israeli and other conflicts, Islam, oil, water, rapid sociopolitical change, trends in development, super-power rivalries, and the search for identity, independence, and peace with justice.

name: HIST3752
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of pre-colonial Africa with particular attention to the rise and fall of African Kingdoms, interaction between different ethnic groups, African trade with other continents, and the impact of foreigners on African societies.

name: HIST3753
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of African perceptions of and responses to the abolition of the slave trade, Western imperialism and colonialism, and the development of nationalism and struggle for independence.

name: HIST3760
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Survey of Southern African societies with an emphasis on the socio-economic and political structure of indigenous societies, the imposition of colonial rule, gendered experiences of colonialism, colonial economies, the rise of nationalism and post-independence developments.

name: HIST3808
catalogName: East Asia to the Mid-Nineteenth Century
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The major problems and issues of traditional Chinese and Japanese history and historiography. Special emphasis on the "Great Tradition" in ideas of both civilizations.

name: HIST3809
catalogName: East Asia Since the Mid-Nineteenth Century
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The reactions of East Asia to the Western threat, and the rise of Asian nationalism, communism, and fascism. Special attention to the tensions caused by the conflict of ideas.

name: HIST3810
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Not open to students who took HIST 3995 when offered as China and the West.
description: China's political, economic, and cultural encounters with Western Powers from the sixteenth century to 1949.

name: HIST3812
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An introduction to the history of India from the Mughal and European invasions of the 16th Century to the present. India's synthesis of Eastern and Western culture, traditional and new, will be the focus.

name: HIST3822
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of patterns of modern China since 1800. Topics will include reforms and revolutions, industrialization and urbanization, and family and population growth. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3832
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3842
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Introduction to the history of the Vietnamese from the late Bronze Age to the present: the ancient culture of the Red River delta, the millennium of Chinese rule, the independent kingdom of Dai Viet and its successors, French colonialism, the Vietnam War, and postwar Vietnam.

name: HIST3863
catalogName: War and Diplomacy in East Asia
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: European struggle for power in Asia since 1842, in the context of the rise of Japan and the reassertion of Chinese power.

name: HIST3991
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Internship in applied history. May be repeated for credit up to a maximum of 12 credits. No more than six credits will count toward the department's major or minor requirements.

name: HIST3993
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: May be repeated for credit. Consent of department head required, normally to be granted before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: HIST4994W
prerequisites: HIST 2100; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to undergraduate history majors in their senior year.
description: These seminars give students the experience of reading critically and in depth in primary and secondary sources, and of developing and defending a position as an historian does.  With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST4996
prerequisites: HIST 2100; open only to history majors in the honors program.
description: Preliminary reading in both primary and secondary sources in consultation with a thesis advisor preparatory to writing the thesis in HIST 4997W.

name: HIST4997W
prerequisites: HIST 2100; HIST 4994 or 4999; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to Honors students.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST4999
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HRTS1007
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Exploration of central human rights institutions, selected human rights themes and political controversies, and key political challenges of contemporary human rights advocacy. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS2203
catalogName: The Holocaust in Print, Theater, and Film
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Representations of the Holocaust, including first-hand accounts and documentaries; artistic choices in genre, structure, imagery, point of view, and the limits of representation. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS2263
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: Any 1000 or 2000 level WGSS course.
description: Discussion of various forms of gendered violence in the United States and in a global context. Physical, sexual, emotional and structural violence; social, political and personal meanings of gendered violence; special emphasis on women.

name: HRTS3028W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: ANTH 2000.
description: An introduction to the study and understanding of Aboriginal ways of life and thought. An exploration of the complexity of contemporary indigenous social orders and land rights issues. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS3042
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Various theories of human rights, both historical and contemporary. Conceptual arguments both in favor and critical of the theory and practice of human rights will be considered, with literature taken primarily from philosophy and political theory.

name: HRTS3050
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The study of international and domestic non-governmental organizations in human rights advocacy and campaigns.

name: HRTS3139
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Provides a critical study of theatre production as political discourse in global areas of conflict and how that discourse defines, or is defined by, human rights issues.

name: HRTS3149W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Human rights-related issues explored via the cinematic medium. Both the substantive content and the technical aspects of the films will be analyzed through a combination of lecture, viewing, and group discussion.

name: HRTS3200W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: HRTS 1007.
description: International and regional human rights law, institutions, and regimes; specialized topics include corporate social responsibility, women's human rights, truth commissions, humanitarian intervention, international criminal law, monitoring, and compliance. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS3201
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Case studies in the emergence and evolution of human rights as experience and  concept.

name: HRTS3202
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Historical and theoretical survey of the evolution of human rights since 1945.

name: HRTS3209
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Political, socioeconomic, environmental, science and engineering challenges of energy sources; comparison of feasibility and sustainability of energy policies around the world.

name: HRTS3212
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Cultural difference and human rights in areas of legal equality, women's rights, political violence, criminal justice, religious pluralism, global security, and race relations.

name: HRTS3220W
description: Ontology and epistemology of human rights investigated through contemporary and/or historical texts. CA 1.

name: HRTS3221
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Latino/a issues related to human, civil and cultural rights, and gender differences.

name: HRTS3230
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed ANTH 3098 when offered as Propaganda, Fake News and Hate Speech
description: Draws on current social science research to understand the effects of false information and hate speech on our politics and culture and to evaluate various private and public initiatives to regulate speech. CA 2.

name: HRTS3232
catalogName: History of Refugees, Migration, and Statelessness
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Forced and voluntary migration and statelessness in the era of the modern state. Topics include the social and political factors influencing population movement; the experience of migration and statelessness; rights of refugees, migrants, and the stateless; immigration policy; international action; and social and political responses to migration.

name: HRTS3252
prerequisites: Open only to non-business students of junior or higher status. Not open to students who have passed or are taking BADM 3252 or BLAW 3252.
description: Social impact and human rights implications related to global operations of multinational corporations; regulatory environment and competitive contexts that govern responsible business conduct on a global scale, how to navigate regulatory mandates and design social responsibility strategies to increase a firm's reputation, reduce costs, and improve its competitive positioning while respecting human rights principles.

name: HRTS3257
catalogName: Assessment for Human Rights and Sustainability
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed ENGR 3257
description: Foundational concepts of human rights and environmental impacts pertaining to global supply chains. Regulations and voluntary standards in engineering-intensive sectors, including infrastructure, biofuels, electronics. Case study analysis of corporate assessment practices for labor rights protection and environmental impacts.

name: HRTS3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit. May be taken for a maximum of 15 credits. Consent of the Minor Director required prior to departure.

name: HRTS3298
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Issues in human rights, history, law and policy, or practices. Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HRTS3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Supervised reading and writing on a subject of special interest to the student. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HRTS3326
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Theories, methods and controversies in the interconnected fields of global health and human rights.

name: HRTS3428
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Examination of the usage of torture by state and non-state actors. Questions include, "Why is torture perpetrated?" "What domestic and international legal frameworks and issues related to the use of torture?" "How effective are existing legal prohibitions and remedies?" "Who tortures?" and "How does torture affect transitional justice?"

name: HRTS3430
catalogName: Evaluating Human Rights Practices of Countries
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Examination of the ways in which governments, businesses, NGOs, IGOs, and scholars assess which human rights are being respected by governments of the world. Hands-on experience in rating the level of government respect for human rights in countries around the world.

name: HRTS3445
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed or are taking ECON 2445
description: Economic approaches to gender inequality in political representation, economic opportunities, access to education, and health.

name: HRTS3505
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The origin, nature, and consequences of white racism as a central and enduring social principle around which the United States and other modern societies are structured and evolve. CA 4.

name: HRTS3540
prerequisites: Instructor consent. May be repeated with a change of topic to a maximum of nine credits.
description: Seminar on topics in theoretical and practice-based knowledge and skills related to human rights. Topics vary by semester.

name: HRTS3563
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of African-American people to 1865, from their West African roots, to their presence in colonial America, through enslavement and emancipation. Adaptation and resistance to their conditions in North America. Contributions by black people to the development of the United States.

name: HRTS3573
catalogName: Asian Indian Women: Activism and Social Change in India and the United States
prerequisites: SOCI 1001, 1251 or 1501; open to juniors or higher.
description: How gender, class, and ethnicity/race structure everyday lives of Asian Indian women in both India and the United States.

name: HRTS3575
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The problematics of digital media and visual representation in conceptualizing, documenting, and visualizing human rights and humanitarian issues. CA 1.

name: HRTS3619
catalogName: Topics in Literature and Human Rights
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Study of literature from various historical periods and nationalities concerned with defining, exploring, and critiquing the idea of universal human rights. May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: HRTS3807
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The role of the Supreme Court in interpreting the Bill of Rights. Topics include freedoms of speech and religion, criminal due process, and equal protection.

name: HRTS3831
catalogName: Human Rights in the United States
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Sociological analyses of human rights issues in the United States, including economic, racial, and gender justice; prisoners' rights and capital punishment; the role of the United States in international human rights agreements and treaties; and struggles on behalf of human rights

name: HRTS3837
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Comparative approach to the study of human rights in the United States and elsewhere around the world from a sociological perspective.

name: HRTS4291
prerequisites: Instructor consent; nine credits of 2000-level or above HRTS courses (six of which may be taken concurrently).
description: Combination of supervised fieldwork within the larger human rights community with regular classroom meetings for reflection/analysis on the application of human rights concepts and practices. Students must secure a satisfactory intern position before the end of the second week of the semester of enrollment in this course; students should be in consultation with the instructor several months in advance.

name: HRTS4996W
description: Research and writing of major project exploring a topic with human rights, with close supervision and production of multiple written drafts.

name: ILCS1001
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students with three or more years of h.s. Italian. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ILCS 1002, 1003, or 1004 or after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in Italian.
description: Elementary Italian grammar. Practice of oral skills through pronunciation and easy conversation. Reading of simple texts and exposure to Italian media and culture. Formerly offered as ILCS 1145.

name: ILCS1002
prerequisites: ILCS 1001 or equivalent. Not open for credit to students with three or more years of high school Italian. Students with questions about placement should contact the head of the Department of Literatures, Cultures and Languages.
description: More elements of grammar and culture with integrated readings. Further practice in conversation and exposure to culture though simple examples from media, politics, and art. Formerly offered as ILCS 1146.

name: ILCS1003
prerequisites: ILCS 1002 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ILCS 1004. May not be taken for credit after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in Italian, or three or more years of high school Italian. Students with questions about placement should contact the head of the Department of Literatures, Cultures and Languages.
description: Intensive oral-aural practice based on selected readings and exposure to a wide range of contemporary cultural themes through materials such as newspaper articles, advertising material, and videos. Emphasis on more complex grammatical structures and vocabulary. Formerly offered as ILCS 1147.

name: ILCS1101
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A survey of Italian Renaissance civilization, with emphasis on literature and intellectual life. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. A knowledge of Italian in not required. CA 1.

name: ILCS1145
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ILCS1146
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ILCS1147
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ILCS1148
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ILCS1149
catalogName: Cinema and Society in Contemporary Italy
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A critical analysis of contemporary Italian society seen through the media of film and literature.  Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Films in Italian with English subtitles. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ILCS1158
catalogName: Italian American Experience in Literature and Film
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Focuses on the Italian American experience as represented in a variety of fields, including literature and cinema. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4.

name: ILCS1160
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The way Italian literary and cinematic culture justified, survived, and fought the terrors of the Fascist totalitarian regime.  Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ILCS1170
prerequisites: May be repeated for credit with a change of subject matter for a maximum of nine credits.
description: The diverse culture of Italy, studied through analysis of sociological,  literary, artistic, and cinematic works from and about a single one of the different Italian regions and that region's cultural centers, such as Rome, Naples, Florence, Palermo, or Venice. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. CA 1.

name: ILCS1193
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally before the student's departure.

name: ILCS3239
prerequisites: ILCS 1004
description: Practice in written and oral composition. Syntax study.

name: ILCS3240
prerequisites: ILCS 3239 or equivalent
description: Further practice in written and oral composition. Treatment of the finer points in syntax.

name: ILCS3247
catalogName: Jewish Literature and Film in 20th Century Italy
prerequisites: ILCS 1004
description: Italy's literary and cinematic representations of Jews in the 20th Century. Jewish identity under Fascism, during World War II, and beyond. Taught in Italian.

name: ILCS3254
prerequisites: ILCS 3237 or 3239 or 3243 or equivalent.
description: Readings from Boccaccio and others with special attention to the problems of social and sexual ethics.

name: ILCS3255W
catalogName: Dante's Divine Comedy in English Translation
description: Dante's poem as a unique synthesis of Medieval culture. Emphasizes its integration of ethics, political thought, and theology with poetic imagination. Taught in English. CA 1.

name: ILCS3258W
description: Cinematic representations of Italian Americans in the works of major directors from the silent era to the present.  Construction of and attempts to dislodge negative stereotypes of Italian American male and female immigrants. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4.

name: ILCS3260W
description: Italian cinema from the silent era to the present. Its genres, such as epic film, melodrama, comedy "Italian-style," "Spaghetti-Westerns," and political cinema. Cinema as a reflection on and comment upon the social and political contexts of Italian history from pre-fascist Italy to modernization and beyond. Taught in English. Films in Italian with English subtitles. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ILCS3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign language program. May be repeated for credit.  Consent of Department Head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: ILCS3298
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary. With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: ILCS3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: ILCS4279
prerequisites: ILCS 1004
description: Advanced language practicum and integration of studies in Italian Literature and Culture.

name: INDS3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be taken for a maximum of 15 credits. Consent of Coordinator of India Studies required prior to departure.

name: INDS3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Supervised reading and writing on a subject of special interest to the student. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: INDS4296W
description: Research and writing of a thesis.

name: INTD2245
catalogName: Introduction to Diversity Studies in American Culture
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: An interdisciplinary introduction to comparative multicultural studies in the United States. Topics may include: African American, Asian American, Latino/a, and Native American cultures; gender, feminism, religious and sexual identities; and disability studies. CA 4.

name: INTD3584
prerequisites: Must be taken concurrently with INTD 3590 and 3594; open to juniors or higher.
description: Discussions based upon assigned readings and led by faculty and invited speakers from outside and within the University. CA 4.

name: INTD3590
prerequisites: Must be taken concurrently with INTD 3584 and 3594; open to juniors or higher.
description: Field experience supervised by the director and an examining committee consisting of the director and two or more faculty members from two departments in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences.

name: INTD3594
prerequisites: Must be taken concurrently with INTD 3590 and 3584; open to juniors or higher.
description: Students make analytic presentations of their field experiences, relating these to the pertinent available literature. Particular issues are discussed with experts invited from inside and outside the University.

name: INTD3594W
prerequisites: INTD 3590 and 3584, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Students make analytic presentations of their field experiences, relating these to the pertinent available literature. Particular urban problems are discussed with invited experts from outside the University.

name: INTD3999
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit.

name: IRIS1001
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing IRIS 1002, 1003, or 1004
description: Development of ability to communicate in Irish, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.

name: IRIS1002
prerequisites: IRIS 1001 or one year of Irish in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing IRIS 1003 or 1004.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Irish, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.

name: IRIS1003
prerequisites:
IRIS 1002 or two years of Irish in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing IRIS 1004.


Not open for credit to students who have passed IRIS 1004.
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Irish-speaking world.

name: JAPN1101
prerequisites: Open only to students with no prior contact with the language. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JAPN 1102, 1103, or 1104.
description: Introduction to elementary Japanese emphasizing speaking, understanding, reading and writing through a communicative approach.

name: JAPN1102
prerequisites: JAPN 1101 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JAPN 1103 or 1104.
description: Further instruction in elementary Japanese emphasizing speaking, understanding, reading and writing skills using a communicative approach involving simple examples from contemporary media and culture.

name: JAPN1103
prerequisites: JAPN 1102 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JAPN 1104.
description: Increasing communicative abilities in Japanese using more examples from contemporary Japanese media and culture.

name: JAPN1104
prerequisites: JAPN 1103 or equivalent
description: Increasing communicative abilities in Japanese with stronger emphasis on vocabulary and grammar using examples from contemporary Japanese media, politics, and culture.

name: JAPN1193
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Credits and hours by arrangement. Prerequisite: Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure.

name: JOUR1002
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 3002.
description: The development of American print journalism from 18th century print shops to 21st century corporations; how journalists and their work have evolved and influenced American life. CA 1.

name: JOUR2000W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Cannot be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 2001, 3005, 3030, 3040, 3045 or 4091.
description: Defining news; exercising news judgment in a diverse society; employing principles of Associated Press style; writing basic news stories. Laboratory offers intensive newswriting exercises.

name: JOUR2001W
prerequisites: JOUR 2000; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Cannot be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 3000,3012, 3013, 3033, 4091.
description: Live reporting using the university and the surrounding community as a laboratory. Emphasis on fact gathering, interviewing, diversity of sources, news judgment and deadline writing.

name: JOUR2065
prerequisites: JOUR 1002, which may be taken concurrently; open to sophomores or higher.JOUR 1002; open to sophomores or higher.
description: Entry-level photojournalism course that develops aesthetic and technical skills for storytelling using mobile equipment such as smartphones.

name: JOUR2111
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W. Open to Journalism majors, others with permission.
description: Introduction to online and multimedia skills used by journalists; emphasis on ethical practices. Students provided portfolio space on a department-maintained site.

name: JOUR3002
prerequisites: JOUR 1002. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 4091.
description: Discussion of such contemporary problems as privacy, good taste, community standards, effectiveness of the press and responsibility of the press.

name: JOUR3005
prerequisites: JOUR 2000.
description: Application of newswriting techniques to online journalism including assembling and producing interactive news stories.

name: JOUR3020
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.
description: Typical subjects: libel, slander, invasion of privacy, obscenity, legal problems of newsgathering, protecting the political process, protecting state secrets, protecting the public welfare.

name: JOUR3030
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W. Recommended preparation: JOUR 2001W.
description: News value; information verification; editing for grammar, spelling, punctuation, and style; content editing; headline writing; search engine optimization; handling visuals; building data visualizations; basic layout and design for print and digital platforms.

name: JOUR3030
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W. Recommended preparation: JOUR 2001W.
description: News value; information verification; editing for grammar, spelling, punctuation, and style; content editing; headline writing; search engine optimization; handling visuals; building data visualizations; basic layout and design for print and digital platforms.

name: JOUR3031
prerequisites: JOUR 3030.
description: Copy and photo selection, copy fitting, photo editing, layout and production for digital and print publications.

name: JOUR3035
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W. Not open for credit to students who have passed JOUR 3095 when offered as Introduction to Podcasting.
description: Researching, recording, writing and producing news podcasts and associated web and social media posts. Ethical considerations.

name: JOUR3040
catalogName: Audio and Video Reporting and Writing
prerequisites: JOUR 2000.
description: Application of newswriting techniques to the broadcast and other media.

name: JOUR3041
prerequisites: JOUR 3040.
description: This is an advanced broadcast journalism class that teaches students how to gather, edit and deliver accurate, newsworthy information for television newscasts. Students develop the skills needed to report  news and organize newscasts through actual experience in and out of class.

name: JOUR3045
prerequisites: JOUR 2000.
description: An introduction to specialized fields such as business, science, education, arts, sports, and entertainment reporting. Students will examine some of the best work in the fields and will consider ethical issues and other problems.

name: JOUR3046E
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W or consent of the instructor. Open to Juniors or higher.
description: Explores specialized coverage of environmental issues by journalists, emphasizing news reporting with the opportunity to produce print, visual and multimedia news reports.

name: JOUR3065
prerequisites:
JOUR 2000W; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 4065.JOUR 2000W; open to juniors or higher.

Not open to students who have passed JOUR 4065.
description: Examines current trends in visual digital journalism; develops skills in photojournalism, multimedia and video storytelling. Instructor approved digital camera required.

name: JOUR3087
prerequisites: JOUR 2000, JOUR 2001 and at least three other journalism credits at the 2000-level or above.
description: Honors students choose topics for their theses or projects, develop research proposals and apply for funding if needed. Students work as a community of scholars to discuss and support each other's work. Usually taken the semester before JOUR 3097, Honors Thesis.

name: JOUR3093
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit with permission of Department Head. Consent of Department Head required before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: JOUR3097
prerequisites: JOUR 2000 and 2001; six additional 2000 level or above credits of JOUR.
description: Students in the Honors Program undertake in-depth research and writing under the guidance of a faculty member. Majors must consult with the departmental Honors Advisor and develop a research proposal in the semester before taking the course.

name: JOUR3098
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: JOUR3111
prerequisites: JOUR 2111
description: Development of online and multimedia skills used by journalists; emphasis on ethical practices. Students will contribute journalism content completed in other courses and develop new content to build a professional portfolio provided on a department-maintained site.

name: JOUR4016
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Students and faculty work together to research, write, edit and produce a publication. May be repeated for credit.

name: JOUR4035
prerequisites: JOUR 2001.
description: Using the Internet, databases, and other computer resources to research and report on the actions of courts, businesses, public agencies, and governments. Consideration of ethical questions.

name: JOUR4065
prerequisites: JOUR 3065; open to juniors or higher.
description: Explores multimedia storytelling through time-based media from a journalistic perspective. Students will develop multimedia narrative skills using photography, videography, and audio to create new media content.

name: JOUR4091
description: Students research, report and write for newspapers, news departments of radio and television stations, and online publications under supervision of professionals.

name: JOUR4099
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Open to qualified students who present suitable projects for independent work in journalism. May be repeated for credit.

name: JOUR4111
prerequisites: JOUR 3111
description: Completion of student journalism portfolios that include examples of journalistic endeavors in print, still and video photography, audio and multimedia packages.

name: KINS1100
prerequisites: Open only to students in Kinesiology programs.
description: Overview of the five pillars of health (exercise, nutrition, sleep, stress and relationships); role of exercise in health promotion and disease prevention across the lifespan; impacts of exercise in leisure time, culture, community, careers and the workplace.

name: KINS1160
prerequisites: This course may be repeated with change of activity and/or skill level,  not  to exceed 3 credits toward graduation of combined AH 1200 and KINS 1160 credits.  Students in the Dept. of Kinesiology may count up to 6 different activities for 6 credits.
description: A variety of lifetime sports and skills are offered. The teaching of each activity will be geared to individual, dual, and team activities. Students who have physical disabilities in the least restrictive environment possible. Participants requiring accommodations should contact the Program Coordinator.

name: KINS2227
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: KINS 1100.
description: Frequency, Intensity, Time, and Type or FITT principle of exercise prescription for apparently healthy adults; healthy populations with special considerations such as children, older adults, and women who are pregnant; and special populations with chronic disease and health conditions such as overweight and obesity, and cardiovascular, pulmonary, metabolic, and musculoskeletal disease.

name: KINS3091
prerequisites: Students must complete all concentration requirements excluding Athletic Training prior to taking an internship.  Open to Kinesiology majors.
description: Field service or experiences in cooperating agencies.  May be repeated for credit.

name: KINS3098
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit with a change in content.

name: KINS3099
prerequisites: Must be of senior standing
description: Laboratory or library research to expand understanding of a specialized topic in sport, leisure, or exercise sciences.  May be repeated for credit with a change in content.

name: KINS3099W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to seniors with consent of the Department Head.
description: Laboratory or library research to expand understanding of a specialized topic in sport, leisure, or exercise sciences.  May be repeated for credit with a change in content.

name: KINS3114
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Provides students majoring in athletic training hands-on experience dealing with athletic injuries.

name: KINS3115
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.  May be repeated to a maximum of four credits.
description: Experiences in a variety of sports medicine settings that will serve to broaden an athletic-training student's awareness of medical coverage of athletic events and other medical personnel involved in athletic health care.

name: KINS3165W
catalogName: Current Research and Issues in Athletic Training
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Acquaint students with the recent research in the field, the components of conducting and publishing research in the field, and preparation for research endeavors at the graduate level. Important issues relevant to the athletic training profession will be discussed.

name: KINS3320
prerequisites: Open only to Kinesiology majors.
description: Examines psychological theories and research related to exercise and sport behavior. Explores the study of how personality and situational variables affect motivation, anxiety, and aggression in exercise and sport. Additional topics to be examined include group processes in exercise and sport, performance enhancement and psychological development through sport.

name: KINS3522
prerequisites: PNB 2264 and 2265; basic mathematics skills; open only to students in Kinesiology Programs.
description: Quantitative and qualitative analyses of sport-related injuries and movements during sport, including the study of linear and angular motion, force and torque, momentum, energy, and equilibrium.

name: KINS3530
catalogName: Aerobic and Resistance Training for Performance
prerequisites: KINS 4500; open only to students in Kinesiology programs, others by consent of instructor.
description: Focuses on the knowledge, skills, and understanding of the scientific principles on which to design individualized aerobic training programs needed for optimal performance, health improvement, disease treatment, and injury prevention. Presents analysis techniques of human physiology specific to aerobic training and performing. Laboratory and field methods to evaluate aerobic ability, lactate threshold, economy, anthropometrics, and aerobic performance characteristics will be discussed.

name: KINS3530W
catalogName: Aerobic and Resistance Training for Performance
prerequisites: KINS 4500; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to students in Kinesiology programs, others by consent of instructor.
description: Focuses on the knowledge, skills, and understanding of the scientific principles on which to design individualized aerobic training programs needed for optimal performance, health improvement, disease treatment, and injury prevention. Presents analysis techniques of human physiology specific to aerobic training and performing. Laboratory and field methods to evaluate aerobic ability, lactate threshold, economy, anthropometrics, and aerobic performance characteristics will be discussed.

name: KINS3545
catalogName: Resistance Training Exercise Techniques and Evaluation
prerequisites: KINS 4500; open only to students in Kinesiology programs, others by consent of instructor.
description: Focuses on the knowledge, skills, and understanding of the scientific principles on which to design individualized resistance training programs needed for optimal performance, health improvement, disease treatment, and injury prevention. Presents analysis techniques of human physiology specific to resistance training and performing. Laboratory and field methods to evaluate anaerobic ability, flexibility, muscular strength and power and body composition will be discussed.

name: KINS3545
catalogName: Resistance Training for Health and Performance
prerequisites: KINS 4500; open only to students in Kinesiology programs, others by consent of instructor.
description: Focuses on the knowledge, skills, and understanding of the scientific principles on which to design individualized resistance training programs needed for optimal performance, health improvement, disease treatment, and injury prevention. Presents analysis techniques of human physiology specific to resistance training and performing. Laboratory and field methods to evaluate anaerobic ability, flexibility, muscular strength and power and body composition will be discussed.

name: KINS3610
prerequisites: Open only to Honors Students in Kinesiology Programs.
description: The student will meet with KINS faculty members and attend laboratory/program staff meetings to survey the opportunities available for future Honors Thesis research.

name: KINS3615
prerequisites: Open only to Honors Students in Kinesiology Programs.
description: The student will identify specific Honors Thesis research questions and will write a library research paper that will serve as the thesis Literature Review.

name: KINS3697W
